awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The Impact of Illegal Crop Cultivation on Agrobiodiversity Change, Social Vulnerability, and Resilience
awd_abstract_narration:
This doctoral dissertation research improvement project investigates how cultivation of illegal crops (e.g. drugs) transforms agricultural biodiversity–also known as agrobiodiversity. Illegal-crop cultivation among agriculturalists is found throughout the world. Such activities transform landscapes, impacting the environment, security and human wellbeing. The project draws on and will further develop theories of social and ecological vulnerability and resilience regarding small farmer agrobiodiversity interactions. Results will be widely disseminated to researchers, local partners, and the public. As part of this research, a Pennsylvania State University undergraduate student will participate as a research assistant, receiving valuable training in geographic research. As a Doctoral Dissertation Improvement award, this project will provide support to enable a promising student to establish an independent research career.

The project will contribute to the geographic analysis of agrobiodiversity loss (a growing global problem) and agrobiodiversity conservation with innovative theoretical and methodological insights on the interactions between agrobiodiversity and shocks and stressors that impact both nature and society. The main research questions are: 1) How do small farmers perceive and manage the risks and opportunities of growing illegal crops as part of their livelihood strategies? 2) How does the cultivation of illegal crops transform the land use and land cover of small farmers, and consequent agrobiodiversity? and 3) What are the social and environmental impacts of illegal crop cultivation on small farmer vulnerability and resilience? To answer these questions, the research project will triangulate three different methods for data generation: semi-structured interviews with agriculturalists, secondary social, demographic, and agricultural data, and remote sensing with satellite imagery. The results will contribute to a framework and methodology for studying cross-scalar relationships between illegal crop cultivation, agrobiodiversity, and social vulnerability.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This research has developed geographic approaches to theories on vulnerability, resource-related conflicts, and land system transitions through the integration of concepts from general frameworks on social-ecological systems and political ecology. Based on a case study in the state of Oaxaca, Mexico, where marijuana and opium poppy have been cultivated at least since the 1960s, this research analyses the role of smallholder agrobiodiversity on mitigating the vulnerability of farmers to structural and physical violence related to the production of these illegal crops in a neoliberal context. Relatedly, it demonstrates the relevance and limitations of local traditional resource governance and conflict management institutions on fostering the ability of smallholder communities to effectively negotiate cooperation (as opposed to violent conflict) internally and with external actors (such as traffickers and state coercive agents) on the management of these illegal crops. Finally, this research shows the contingent emergence of non-traditional livelihoods and landscapes in a context of rapid global change, where processes of forest transitions and de-agrarianization related to the volatility of illegal crop profitability and related land abandonment happen only partially and in heterogeneous ways within the same region, as part of a complex nexus of land and migration and their coupling. Methodological approaches in this research included 76 structured/semi-structures interviews with smallholder farmers, harvest gatherers (or middlemen), and former soldiers in four state prisons. Methods also included two semi-structured interviews with key informants, a statistical analysis of official secondary data, and the production and analysis of eighteen Sentinel 2 satellite images.

 

Findings were presented in five annual academic conferences, as well as in peer review scientific journals that have already been published (two papers) and will be submitted for publication shortly (other two papers). The annual academic conferences included the following: (1) the 2019 Center for Research and High Studies on Social Anthropology Conference (CIESAS, campus Oaxaca, Mexico); (2) the 2020 Conference of Latin Americanist Geographers (CLAG); (3) the 2020 International Conference of Researchers in Family Studies (Autonomous University of Tlaxcala, Mexico); (4) the 2021 International Conference on Regional Development (University of Guanajuato, Mexico); and (5) the 2021 Dimensions of Political Ecology (DOPE) Conference. One chapter of the dissertation was published in the Geoforum journal by the name of “Agrobiodiversity conservation with illegal-drug crops: An approach from the prisons in Oaxaca, Mexico” (https://doi.org/10.1016/j.geoforum.2020.10.012). A second paper on “Agrobiodiversity change in violent conflict and post-conflict landscapes” was published also in Geoforum (https://doi.org/10.1016/j.geoforum.2021.11.010). A third paper will be submitted to the journal World Development in January 2022 by the name “The illegal crop-violence nexus: Conflict and cooperation in autonomous communities in Oaxaca, Mexico”. We plan to submit a fourth paper to the journal Land Use Policy in March 2022 by the name of” Land use change and migration amidst the opium poppy collapse in the Southern Highlands of Oaxaca, Mexico (2016-2020)”.
